intro: Chascanum garipense, commonly known as the Garip Peninsula chascanum, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants such as buckwheat and smartweeds. The plant is characterized by its upright stems and clusters of small, pinkish to reddish flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture. Chascanum garipense is adapted to grow in rocky and well-drained soils, often found in high-altitude environments.
